segments.text: Well, thank you so much, Sam, for your wonderful introduction.
And thank you, Charles, for your great welcoming remarks.
And I want to thank Pat for her hospitality.
And I want to thank the entire UTEP community for inviting me to join with you in this wonderful event, an event that not only celebrates books, but celebrates the book as an artifact.
We have with us two remarkable young women who will be this year's Carl Herzog honor recipients.
It's really a great pleasure to meet them.
And I have to say that the Whistler book, I'm originally from Lowell, Massachusetts, where James McNeil Whistler was born.
So there's always some connection, isn't there?
We mentioned Whistler, Massachusetts, and your father lives in Massachusetts.
So there's always these little connections that we make when we travel far afield.
I'm just so impressed by the fact that I've come to Shangri-La on the border.
I have to say, when Sam drove me up the hill yesterday and I saw these remarkable buildings in this architecture, I first thought, wow, this is southwestern architecture.
And then I said, wait a minute, maybe it's Asian.
And then, of course, then it's Butanese.
And now I find that you are quite correctly anointed as Shangri-La at the border.
Wonderful phrase.
Well, I tell you, I look up here and say, still my heart.
To see the dust jacket of a book that you work on for 10 years, all of a sudden, you know, 15 feet, however, it's quite an exciting experience, I have to say.
Even after all these years, we're now entering the fifth year of publication.
As Sam mentioned, the book was published in 1995.
We've had seven editions, six in hardcover, and each one is a, this is a book arts gathering, so we do appreciate, I guess, the niceties between printings and editions.
I'm a person who believes that a book like mine, which is a nonfiction work, which deals with living people as well as deceased people, can't help but to be a work in progress.
And you say, how is that possible, a book that's
published and produced and designed and issued between hard covers, how can a completed work be a work in progress?
Well, I guess that kind of brings us to the title of the lecture today.
Actually, I prefer to call it a talk.
I think a lecture is a little too pedantic for a person of my temperament.
I'm much more comfortable talking with you and having a conversation with you.
But Among the Gently Mad, of course, is a play on the title of A Gentle Madness.
And it is a continuing work in my view.
Those of you who have had an opportunity to read the preface to the paperback, you'll note that I have had an opportunity to bring up to date at least five of the major stories in there.
The great collector of modern first editions, Carter Burton, died in February of 1996 and his collection went to the Morgan Library.
Then we had a famous chef from Chicago, Chef Louis Zafmari, when he passed away, also in 1996.
He saw to it that his 250,000 books and perhaps a million culinary objects went to a variety of institutions to help them support museums and libraries and scholarship.
And so there was another collector who had a transition, which I felt obligated to report
on and to my readers.
And then we also have the passing on of Dr. Haskell Norman, who is arguably the greatest collector of science books and medical books, again also in 1996.
It really was a threesome of three extraordinary collectors who in each, in his own way, contributed to the cycle of books and collecting.
The subtext of A Gentle Madness, it's wonderful to have a title
that incorporates and embraces the word madness.
I think that's one of the things that has really resonated with readers when you're talking about emotion and human nature and passion and obsession, of course.
It was an inspiration, I have to say, when I came up with the title of Gentle Madness.
And when I heard Sam say the new title of the new book is Lions at the Gate, then I whispered to myself, well, for now it is.
It could change.
And that is maybe the 10th or 12th
different title that I've had.
It's really been much tougher to come up with a title for this new book.
I like the image of Lyons, who are the guardians of libraries, historically, traditionally, going back hundreds of years.
And I'll tell you, this is a plea, this is a request.
I've made requests to the queries to the Morgan Library in New York with their Lyons outside.
to the New York Public Library where there are lions outside, to the Boston Public Library where there are wonderful lions inside.
The Art Institute of Chicago, I believe, has lions.
The British Museum has lions.
Nobody can tell me where this tradition started.
I mean, I've asked the head librarians, the Charles Pierce at the Morgan Library.
You know, that's a good question, they say.
We don't know.
Well, I'm still looking.
But I like the idea of the lion as the guardian of the library, the guardian of the book.
And if you think about it, the lion, of course,
facing outward is protecting the library.
But if you turn them around, then I guess the image can almost be a predator.
And the book is under attack in many quarters.
We have suggestions.
There will be a chapter in my new book, which I call The Once and Future Library.
And it's a case study examination of the San Francisco Public Library situation, which many of you may have read about in the New Yorker magazine with Nicholson Baker.
I spent two weeks out there attempting to get every little nuance and every little detail on just what happened there.

What was this calculus that was put into play that actually persuaded these people that they could build a library without books, that they could actually build a place that was quite beautiful, have an atrium with wonderful sound
acoustics in there.
If you can believe it, a reading room is supposed to be quiet.
You can hear pin drops in there.
You can have string quartets play in there, but you really don't have much room for people to sit down and read.
And then you wonder what kind of books they're going to read because they sent 500,000 books off to a landfill without even documenting what books that they were.
And now, just within the last six weeks, the people of San Francisco have had a post-occupancy evaluation
which reports that it will take $30 million to now repair this state-of-the-art future library and to make it a real legitimate library.
Well, it's a very interesting case study, and I know that you've had some concerns here in El Paso, and I certainly don't mean to be making any comparisons.
I think we all have to deal with our own library situations, but I think that there is a cautionary tale there that you should all be alert to and you should study and pay attention to.
Well, I guess I'm jumping ahead of myself.
I usually talk about the new book towards the end of the talk.
But among the gently mad, who are the gently mad?
I guess all of us who love books have a touch of the gentle madness.
Sam mentioned that I am from Massachusetts.
I spent my professional life working in Worcester, much of it, as a book review editor, 13 years.
than as an independent scholar and a writer and a historian of books and book culture.
And very early on, I did an essay for a Boston magazine, and the subject of this essay was 1200 years of collecting in Boston.
Now you wonder how that is possible.
You know, Boston, we've only been here for 300 years or so.
But if you look at 350 years at Harvard, and if you look at 200 years at the Massachusetts Historical Society, and 200 years at
the American Antiquarian Society, and you go on and on, and the math adds up to about 1,200 years.

And what I did was write a kind of a narrative history of all of these institutions, and not just the collection and the gathering of the books, but the kind of passion and obsession that went into building these collections.
And it dawned on me at one really almost epiphanous moment that it is really the passion, the obsession,

of the quirky eccentric collector who is responsible for preserving so much of what we know of our literature, our culture, our history, and that without the efforts of these determined, driven individuals, so much of what we know of ourselves and value of ourselves would be lost forever.
So I wrote this piece, and it was published in 1988, I guess it was, and had a very nice response.
And my wife, God bless her, I remember, prior to the publication of this piece, I like to read to her what I write aloud.
I get a good feeling for the rhythms and the nuances and the organization.
And I remember reading this opening paragraph for her.
I started at Harvard University on the second floor of the Houghton Library, and with the death mask of John Keats,
in the Amy Lowell room, and then I moved across the Charles River and up to Beacon Hill to the Boston Athenaeum.
And she said, you know, there's your book.
You know, the light flashes over you.
This could be the book that you were born to write.
Excuse me just a second here.
And so began this quixotic
attempt to try and document as much as I could the creation of the great libraries and the efforts and the contributions put forward and put forth by these private collectors.
Now, how do we get the title of Gentle Madness?
I've worked in Worcester, Massachusetts, and in Worcester is, believe it or not, the oldest library, which is an example of a distinctively American species of library.
the American Antiquarian Society, which was established in 1812 by a gentleman named Isaiah Thomas.
Isaiah Thomas was known in his day as the most prominent printer.
He was a patriot.
He fought at the battles of Lexington and Concord.
He published the first reports of the battles in his Massachusetts spy.
After the war, he was a great printer, binder.
He owned his wood factories to make paper.
He wrote the first history of printing in North America, a book that is still in print.
We don't remember him really for all of these things today.
We remember him for his book collection, which became the American Antiquarian Society, and which became the first of a distinctively American institution, which is a library.

founded by a book collector with a great collection, which is really not connected or associated with any academic institution, but exists with its own endowment, with its own staff, with its own librarians.
It's there to serve scholars.
The AAS was the first, but we also have in the United States the Morgan Library in New York, the wonderful Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C., the Huntington Library in California,
Park Library in Los Angeles.
I mean, you can go on and on.
There are the John Carter Brown Library in Providence, Rhode Island.
And each one reflects a certain kind of a passion, Americana, Shakespeare.
Morgan is, of course, great illuminated manuscripts.
Huntington, of course, is wonderful British things.
The wonderful charts are wonderful things.
It's a distinctively American institution.
Well, when Isaiah Thomas died at the
ripe old age of, I think it was 92.
His grandson said in tribute that grandfather was afflicted at the earliest of ages with the gentlest of infirmities.
He was a bibliomaniac.
I remember reading that phrase and saying, well, you know, there's my title right there.
And thus we have a gentle madness.
And I also take note of the subtitle.
Being a good journalist, I've learned

especially as a book editor, that if you have a long subtitle that pretty much summarizes your book, wherever it's reviewed, you're going to get a nice big boldface ad for free at the top of the piece, Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books.
I have a definition in the introduction, a German bibliographer by the name of Hans Bohata, who said, the bibliophile is the master of his books, the bibliomaniac, their slave.
And then he also acknowledges that you never really know when you cross the line.
And I'm often asked, am I a bibliomaniac?
One local reviewer in Worcester who said, well, Nick Basbane may not be a bibliomaniac, but he certainly is on the cusp.
And I kind of like that.
I moderated a forum at the American Antiquarian Society a couple of weeks ago, and I was introduced there as a person who really collects collectors

And I guess I like that a lot, because I really do see these people who I've gotten to know and spent a lot of time with them, learning not only about their collections and their collecting and their libraries and their passions, but have become friends in many cases with them, have followed their fortunes.
And I guess I can never afford to own a first folio of Shakespeare.
but I certainly could handle one, as Abel Berland allowed me to do in Chicago.
He'll be in my new book, a chapter on scholar collectors.
I couldn't stay away from the collectors.
The new book is a continuation of themes.
It will involve many book culture considerations, but I will have a chapter on people I consider scholar collectors, another chapter on scholar booksellers.
technology, preservation, libraries through history, libraries of the future.

I'm really going off the deep end here, perhaps, which may in a few minutes bring us to Stephen Blumberg, my book thief, by the way, who is the example of the collector who kind of falls off the cliff.
Now, there was a review in the local paper, which I'm grateful for, very well written.
Thank you very much, sir, if you're here.
The headline said, book croaks.
which is a great phrase.
But I have to say that the book is really not about the theft of books.
I maintain that bibliomania is a very productive thing.

And I think that these libraries and these great collections, the great collections that you have here, I'm sure that a good number of them I've seen, I know a good number of them, come to you courtesy of your friends, of private individuals, of collectors.
It isn't just these individual libraries, by the way, that I've mentioned.

that exist because of collectors, the great collections in many libraries outside, in universities, Harvard, here at HRC, which I have a chapter on at the Lansom Center at the University of Texas in Austin.
Many, many gifts there from collectors, people who have followed their passions.
So then people say to me, well, if you're writing about the
the productive aspects of bibliomania.
What in the world is Steven Blumberg doing in there?
Why do you have this chapter, which you call the Blumberg Collection?
Now, for those of you who haven't read the book, chapter 13, just coincidental that it happens to be chapter 13.
And I noticed, by the way, that you have a room over in the library called the Blumberg Auditorium.
I don't think there's any relationship.
I mean, it's kind of cute.
Stephen Carey Blumberg was arrested 10 years ago in Ottomua, Iowa, by a squadron of 17 FBI agents.

And when they went into his Victorian home, they seized 23,800 books, which he had gathered over the previous 20 years from 268 libraries in 45 states, two Canadian provinces in the District of Columbia.
23,000 books, initially valued at perhaps as high as $20 million.
Later, more realistically, determined to be about $5 million.
The point is, this fellow had spent 20 years traveling the United States, coming... I don't know if he came here, by the way.
I should check.
He may have.
He loved Texas, by the way.
He actually spent a lot of time down here.
He was kind of in the antique business.
He spent 20 years assembling this library.
He had a Nuremberg Chronicle, which is the last great history of the world written prior to the discovery of America, so it makes it very, very interesting.
The author of that book quite wisely left a few blank pages at the back so you could add breaking events such as the discovery of America.
He got his copy of the Nuremberg Chronicle from Claremont College in California.
He had the state of Connecticut's own copy of the first book printed in Connecticut.
And he got that out of the State Library of Connecticut, which is not open to the public.
We still don't know how he got in there.
It was in a vault.
He had books from the University of Michigan.
He had books from Harvard University, the Library of Congress, 268 libraries.
And he actually, now I called him, I call that chapter the Plumberg Collection.
A cute title.
But it does, it does illustrate the difference between a collection and what we call an accumulation.
You know, there are people like the famous Cauldre Brothers in New York who died literally under the weight of all their books.
You know, they collapsed.
But this was just a mass of things.
There was no focus.
Blumberg had a focus.
A collection is a focused extension of your personality.
It reflects your interests in life, your passions in literature or music or whatever.
Stephen Blumberg's passion was Americana, was architecture, was design.
Did I mention that he owned 50,000 doorknobs, antique doorknobs?
He had 120,078 RPM records.
He had 10,000 stained glass windows.
I was thinking at dinner last night in this Tiffany room here at the Camino Real Hotel.
I thought, boy, if Lumberg had ever been here, he would have figured out a way.
There's no question.
His ever-always, we say, he would travel.
He would find condemned structures.
His passion was Victoriana.
And he is quite an authority on these things, by the way.
He would go in and he would strip the place of the stained glass windows or the doorknobs or the fixtures or the fireplace, whatever he could find that was old, that was interesting to him.
Did I mention that he also was a person of independent means?
You would never know it to see him.
He lived, you would think in first seeing him, but he's kind of a homeless person.
But he really was living in the 19th century.
His family is from Minnesota.
They are the largest single owners of real estate in St.
Paul.
So there are some means there.
I think the last estimate I read was $250 million.
Why couldn't he buy the books that he wanted?
He could certainly afford to do that.
But he chose to go and select, as he said.
And he did.

very interesting when he was arrested fully 95 percent of the books that he had were never known to have been missing until the day they were recovered only five percent had been reported missing now this is again you talk about cautionary tales a lot of a lot of like and it's every place in america believe in harvard university
Every place with the greatest security systems were victimized by this fellow.
He really was a brilliant master thief.
He was a cat burglar.
I mean, if you have a chance to read chapter 13, you'll find that he would affect the...
the demeanor of a professor.
He managed to get some documents that identified him as a scholar.
He would travel around with a briefcase.
He would go in.
He would introduce himself.
He'd find his way around.
He'd identify the books that he would want to come back and get later.
How did he get in?
Well, he would find a way.
I don't know how he would do it, but he'd probably find your desk.
I'm talking you generically now, Pat.
But he would find your keys.
He would remove them.
He'd make a copy.
He'd come back later at night.
He would defeat security systems.
He'd back up a pickup truck.
He'd load up with books.
And he did this for 20 years, and he really didn't get caught through any fault of his own.
He had a good friend, good friend in quotes, who got in trouble with the law and turned him in for a bounty of $56,000.
Well, at this birth book, Gentle Madness, I already had the title.
I was working on it.
It had a focus.
I knew where I was going.
I had already sold it.
The contract was signed.
And then I read in the newspaper about the arrest of this fellow in Atomua, Iowa.
And I knew instantly that, you know, it's going to take a little longer to finish this book, I'm afraid.
And so I went out to Des Moines.
I spent two weeks there, got to know Mr. Blumberg, spent a day with him.
He took me down.
He was out on bail while the trial was pending.
On the Saturday, when Court was not in session, he called my room.
He said, would you like to, he had this gravelly voice, would you like to spend a day in the life of Stephen Blumberg?
And I said, what time?
He said, 10 minutes.
And I was out in front of the hotel.
We were on our way.

We went down to a town where he took me into one of the nine warehouses that he is known to have maintained, one down here in Texas, by the way, throughout the United States, where he kept his stained glass windows, his antiques, all of these remarkable things.
The library, by the way, began as a reference library.
He wanted to know more about his antiques.
And then one of the great quotes is, well, you know, us collectors, once we get started, we can't stop.
And I said, well, how does that explain?
He said, Americana, I love Americana.
I said, well, how does that explain the incunabula?
You know, these are books that are 500 years old, published prior to 1501, published in the cradle period of printing.
We call them incunables, which literally means from the cradle.
You know, he had, well, the Nuremberg Chronicle was an incunable.
He had a hundred of these books.
You know, I mean, this is a remarkable collection of...
of 500-year-old books.
And that's when he said, well, you know collectors, once we get started, we really can't stop.
What proved to be part of his undoing was that he collected trophies.
He had three scrapbooks.
When he removed the books, he took them back to a tumbler.
And he would take out, he didn't hurt the books.
He was very good to the books.
He loved the books.
He was passionate about the books.
And when he took them back, he took out the book weights, and he put them all very neatly, pardon me, geographically, and pasted them into these three scrapbooks.
And we talk about jumping ahead, and how I continue to collect my collectors.
I just this summer acquired those three scrapbooks.
They are now

in my collection and they i paid a dear price for them i have to say but uh thankfully the person who had them i mean the federal government had them they and they still have their marking on the exhibit number one and uh and then they were given to creighton university along with books that they couldn't determine the ownership of and creighton
decided that they didn't want to keep them, and they were consigned to a bookseller, and they actually had an auction, and I was given the opportunity to get these.
They belong in my collection, I think.
But they're very, very interesting.
You can really follow this progress around the country.
My daughter is a first-year student at Smith College out in Western Massachusetts, and I know the director of special collections there very well, a fellow by the name of Martin Antonetti.
I was telling them that I had just recently acquired these notebooks,
These scrapbooks, he said, Nick, he said, did he ever get to Smith?
I said, you don't know?
He said, no.
I said, well, let me check.
Well, I sent him an email.
I couldn't bear to call him and break the news.
But there are six different Smith book plates in there.
And two with shelf numbers.
So I said, we don't know what books they were.
But in two instances, there were shelf numbers.
So I said, Martin, let me know what books they were.
And he didn't get back to me on that.
But he has an Ivy League section.
He has a Southwest section.
He has a California section.
And very neatly put together.
Really has a remarkable window into this guy.
Did I mention?
I didn't.
That his trial, he was convicted, by the way.
At his trial, his defense, for what amounted to the only instance in the history of American jurisprudence,
of a case of what I call criminal bibliomania, where the defense was not guilty by reason of insanity.
This is what he claimed.
I thought it was ridiculous until I got to the trial.
And you know, it wasn't that frivolous after a while.
It was demonstrated at this trial.
Then he had had nine institutional admittances.
I'll have to, when I do the text of this talk, I'll have to find a better noun than that.
But he was committed in nine different instances where he was treated, and then always came back to breaking into abandoned houses, going into condemned structures.
Now what's the latest update of Mr. Blumberg?
He did it seven years.
He was released.
He was told to go near no libraries or bookstores or museums or condemned houses.
He was arrested in Des Moines.
He was in a condemned house, stripping the thing of doorknobs, and he's going back for five years.
Go figure.
While he was in prison, we had to maintain the long correspondence.
A fascinating character.
I don't know why nobody from Hollywood hasn't come forward to do a movie on this guy.
If you're going to do a crime story as a writer, I mean, what better story could you possibly have?
Here's a person whose crime idea is that he loves books too much.
He really does.
I mean, there's no murder, there's no rape, there's no child abuse, there's no battering, there's no trucks.
Everything that was stolen was returned in a better shape than it was when it was taken.
So if you have to do a crime story, that's not bad.
I taped the seven hours.
So I have this wonderful archive of tape-recorded conversation with him.
And as we're driving down to a tumble, you can hear him say at one point, shut the tape recorder off.
Okay, I shut it off.

He was holding out as a bargaining chip the fact that he knew where all the books came from, because he had taken out all the book plates and he had disguised provenance, as we say in the book world, with prior ownership.
So he pretty much figured that he could help them, and if he helped them determine where the books came from, then that might get him a lighter sentence.
He said, you know the Uncle Tom's cabin I think I got from Harvard?
I said, USC.
University of Southern California.
Didn't get it from Harvard, got it from USC.
They discovered that at some point.
He was also working very closely with the FBI to tell them where he got the books.

At one point, there was a special collections librarian from Duke, a gentleman by the name of John Sharp, who went to the warehouse in Omaha, Nebraska, where I was admitted, the only journalist allowed inside, to see these books.
before they were returned.
The FBI agent said, what in the world do you want to come here for?
All it looks like is a library of old books.
No kidding.
That's the idea.
It looks like a library.
That's what it is.
It is a library.
You wonder why a reporter or a journalist always has to see something where you can't really rely on what somebody tells you it looks like or secondhand descriptions.
If you read that chapter, I begin it
with this conversation with the FBI agent saying, why in the world do you want to come out here?
And I go in and I guess what really didn't impress me immediately was the massive books.
What really impressed me were these stenciled signs on the shelves.
University of Michigan, University of Texas, USC, Harvard, Massachusetts Historical Society.
That kind of crystallized for me what this story was about, because he was not only just stealing books, he really was stealing part of our national patrimony, and that is a grievous crime.
You know, I was thinking earlier when you were saying that you have books overdue, I was smiling, I was thinking Clearwater, Florida, you know?
Have you met the story down in Clearwater where these two people had books overdue and they arrested them?
And everybody said, well, I did this just for books.
Just for books?
Well, I said, you know, with all due respect, you've had books out for two years.
Maybe it's not a bad idea to have a little bit of an object lesson.
And then maybe the books won't be read, just books.
But people say to me, I'm a journalist, you know.
You've spent 15 years now writing about nothing but books.
I said, well, what would you have me write about, you know?
I mean, if not books, what?
Oxygen?
I mean, food?
The essentials of life?
I mean, what better thing, as far as I'm concerned, can we write about than books?
We celebrate here, and I failed to mention that because we do honor book design here, the engraving here is called The Book Fool.
It was drawn by Albrecht Durer in the late 1800s.
late 1580, this particular book was printed in 1494 in Basel, in Das Basel or wherever, Das Naranschief, the original Ship of Fools.
And the number one fool in the whole Navy of the Ship of Fools was the book fool.
And so there he is there.
And I remember seeing that picture, that illustration, and I wonder, there it is.
Wonderful.
Well, there it is.
That's 1494.
wood engraving.

I remember when I sent in my manuscript, my 1300s age manuscript to New York, I just kind of Xeroxed this wood cut and put it on top and I said to the editor, try and do something with this with a dust jack.
And maybe if you can just kind of suggest the decorations around the border there.
So I'm not a book designer.
The young woman who did design the book, she did a splendid, wonderful job.
And I have to take credit for the art and for the suggestion.
And I really think that this is one instance where the appearance of a book has just made such a fantastic, you say you can't sell a book by its cover.
Well, I'd like to think that we have seven printings because of the content.
and the stories that I tell.
But I also know that in Christmas of 1995 or 1996, Rizzoli's bookstore in New York gave it a whole window.
And my wonderful mother was in New York to see some plays.
She's 80 years old.
She's walking down Fifth Avenue and she sees the window.
But all copies of my book are in this splendid poster.
And she went in and she said, that's my son.
You have to give me that poster.
I thought she was crazy.
And they refused.
I said, no, mother, they need the poster.
You know, they're trying to sell books.
It's a wonderful poster.
She had to have it.
But she didn't get it, as it turns out.
But it's really quite a thrill still to see it displayed on a screen like this here.
I failed to mention earlier that this is my first trip to El Paso.
I didn't really believe how far west and how far south I was until I did look at the map.
We from New England tend to be pretty smug.
We take pride in the fact that the first printing press in what we now know as the United States was set up in 1639 in Cambridge.
And there the first, the base, what we know is the base of what was printed.
Well, you come down here and you realize that the first press in North America was established in Mexico 100 years earlier.
And the first book in North America was printed, you know, I don't know if it's within eyesight of where we stand, but it is here.
And when Mr. Herzog came here, as he said, as a tenderfoot Yankee,
He came and became known as the printer at the pass.

I just think that is such a delightful, wonderful story and that he celebrated the book not only as an object and as an artifact and as a visual performance but also as a container and a bearer and a vessel of information and the fact that you celebrate his accomplishments and you celebrate him and you have this wonderful competition and you recognize these
wonderful young women who have produced beautiful books.
I just tip my hat to you and I thank you very much for inviting me to join with you here and to share in this celebration of books and to honor these young women for their splendid accomplishments.
And I thank you very much for coming out on a beautiful day.
My wife tells me it's 10 degrees at home.
a little bit of snow overnight, and going down below zero.
And I said, you should be with me in El Paso.
And she said, well, next time.
And I really, truly hope that there is a next time, and that you look out for Lions of the Gate next year.
Thank you very much for coming out for session.
